title: R45386
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies with various functions, such as managing federal property and regulating financial institutions. This report focuses on funding for these agencies in Title V of the bill, along with general provisions in Title VII and provisions on Cuba sanctions. Other agencies funded by the bill include the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. The FSGG appropriations bill funds independent agencies with various functions, including financial regulation. The bill has existed in its current form since 2007 and funds agencies like the Department of the Treasury. President Trump's FY2019 budget request included $2.3 billion for independent agencies. The budget request on February 12, 2018, included $2.3 billion for independent agencies funded through the FSGG appropriations bill, with $282 million allocated for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported a bill for FY2019 with approximately $1.2 billion for FSGG independent agencies and $255 million for the CFTC in the Agriculture appropriations bill. The total funding would have been $1.4 billion, $0.9 billion below the President's request, with the largest difference in funding for the GSA. Title IX of the bill included provisions related to financial regulation, such as bringing the CFPB into the fold. The House of Representatives passed H.R. 6147, which included H.R. 6258 as Division B, shifting funding among FSGG agencies. The Senate reported S. 3107 with $2.3 billion for FSGG independent agencies, similar to the President's request but with differences in funding for components like the GSA. The Senate began considering H.R. 6147 on July 24, 2018, incorporating S. 3107 as Division B. The Senate passed an amended version of H.R. 6147 in 2018, which included S. 3107 as Division B. The bill did not include Title IX legislative provisions, such as the shift in CFPB funding. A conference committee convened on September 13, 2018, but no report was issued before the fiscal year ended. Continuing appropriations were provided through December 21, 2018, due to a funding lapse for the FSGG agencies in the 115th Congress. In the 115th Congress, appropriations were passed leading to a funding lapse for FSGG agencies and others on December 22, 2018. The House passed two consolidated appropriations bills in January 2019, providing $2.3 billion and $2.5 billion for FSGG agencies in separate bills. In the 116th Congress, a conference report was agreed upon by the House and Senate on the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019, providing full FY2019 funding for government operations, including FSGG provisions. The act, signed into law as P.L. 116-6, allocated $1.9 billion for FSGG independent agencies, such as the CFTC, but did not include financial regulatory provisions from the House in the 115th Congress. The Title IX financial regulatory provisions passed by the House in the 115th Congress allocated approximately $0.6 billion less than the President's request, with most of the difference coming from funding for the GSA. The conference report stated that language from previous appropriations committees reports should be considered as indicating congressional intent. Tables 1, 2, and 3 provide details on the FSGG appropriations measures and amounts requested by the President for independent agencies. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission oversees derivatives markets, including futures and swaps trading, fraud prevention, and investor protection. Congressional authorization jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate agriculture committees despite the shift towards financial variables in futures trading. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission oversees derivatives markets, including futures and swaps trading, fraud prevention, and investor protection. Congressional jurisdiction for the CFTC is under the House and Senate agriculture committees due to its historical ties to agricultural markets. The Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC oversight, along with regulated futures and options markets. The CFTC's oversight expanded to include swaps markets with a $240 trillion notional value in the US, in addition to futures and options markets valued at $34 trillion. Funding for the CFTC increased to $281.5 million in FY2019. Legislation in the 115th and 116th Congresses proposed varying appropriations for the CFTC. The CPSC is a federal agency focused on reducing consumer harm from various products. They create safety standards, work on voluntary standards, ban unsafe products, monitor recalls, educate consumers, conduct research, and collaborate with governments. The Administration requested $123.5 million for CPSC in FY2019, with $5.6 million for workforce development. In the FY2019 budget request for the CPSC, $5.6 million is allocated to workforce development, $72.6 million to prevent hazardous products, $37.2 million to respond quickly to harmful products, and $8.1 million for communication. Employee compensation makes up a significant portion of the budget. H.R. 6147 proposed $127 million in appropriations for CPSC, $3.5 million more than the request. An administrative provision in the bill would delay implementing a safety standard for off-road vehicles until certain conditions are met. In the 115th and 116th Congress, appropriations bills proposed $126 million for off-road vehicles (ORVs), with specific conditions to be met before implementing a safety standard. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 6147 appropriated $127 million for the CPSC, including provisions for ORVs. $800,000 is allocated for the grant program under the Virginia Graeme Baker Pool and Spa Safety Act. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) oversees federal election administration, established by the Help America Vote Act of 2002. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) oversees federal election administration, established by the Help America Vote Act of 2002. The EAC was given responsibilities for the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA) under HAVA, with a budget request of $9.2 million for FY2019. In the 115th Congress, there were appropriations of $10.1 million in the House and $9.2 million in the Senate for the EAC. H.R. 648 proposed $9.2 million for the Election Assistance Commission (EAC), with $1.5 million for transfer to NIST. The FCC, established in 1934, regulates communications and is funded by regulatory fees. The FCC is given authority to review and adjust regulatory fees based on its appropriation. For FY2019, $339 million is provided for FCC salaries and expenses, with specific directives on parental rating systems and local TV programming transmissions. The FCC must report on the rating system's accuracy and the Oversight Monitoring Board's effectiveness, as well as comply with the STELAR Act of 2014 regarding local TV transmissions. The FCC is directed to provide a full analysis to ensure decisions on market modification are comprehensively reviewed under the STELAR Act of 2014. P.L. 116-6 also contains a provision prohibiting the FCC from changing rules governing the Universal Service Fund. The FDIC Office of the Inspector General audits and investigates the FDIC's operations and programs, funded through deposit insurance funds. The FDIC Office of the Inspector General is funded through deposit insurance funds to ensure independence. The President's request included $43.0 million for the FDIC OIG in FY2019. The FEC administers and enforces compliance with campaign finance regulations and requested $71.3 million for FY2019. In the 115th Congress, H.R. 6147 as passed by the House and Senate would have appropriated $71.3 million. Sections of the legislation related to campaign finance policy included prohibitions on SEC rules regarding political contributions and enforcement of the "prior approval" rule. The Senate-passed bill retains language prohibiting reporting political contributions as a condition of government contracts. P.L. 116-6 appropriated $71.3 million, with provisions prohibiting spending on additional SEC or contractor disclosure. The FTC's responsibilities include consumer protection and maintaining competition in various industries. The FTC enforces laws to maintain competition in industries, educate consumers, and prevent unfair business practices. Its funding sources include direct appropriations, premerger filing fees, and Do-Not-Call Registry fees. The President's FY2019 budget requested $156.7 million in direct appropriations, $136 million in filing fees, and $17 million in registry fees, totaling $309.7 million. In FY2018, the FTC received $164.3 million in direct appropriations, with a total budget of $306.3 million. In FY2019, the FTC's total budget was $311.7 million, $2 million above the budget request. 55% of the appropriations were for consumer protection activities, while 45% were for promoting competition. The bill restricted funds from being used for responsibilities under FDICIA Section 151. The Senate-passed version of H.R. 6147 would have provided the FTC with a total budget of $309.7 million, assuming $136 million in HSR filing fees and $17 million in DNR fees. None of the funds could be used for implementing FTC's full responsibilities under Section 151 of the FDICIA. The General Services Administration (GSA) administers federal civilian procurement policies for federal buildings, property disposal, and records management. It manages funding for former Presidents and presidential transitions through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF), which is funded by rental payments from federal agencies leasing GSA space. Congress allocates FBF revenue for construction, repairs, rentals, and building operations expenses. The General Services Administration (GSA) administers federal civilian procurement policies and manages funding for former Presidents through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF). The FBF has limitations on obligating funds exceeding Congress's approval. GSA's operating accounts are funded separately from the FBF. GSA's total funding includes FBF appropriations and operating account appropriations. Table 4 shows GSA's funding amounts for FY2018, the President's FY2019 request, and the FY2019 amounts from H.R. 6147. The President proposed a limit of $10.132 billion from the FBF's available revenue for GSA's real property activities for FY2019, an increase of $1.058 billion more than FY2018. In the 115th Congress, the House-passed H.R. 6147 included a limit of $8.623 billion, while the Senate-passed H.R. 6147 included a limit of $9.633 billion. In the 116th Congress, P.L. 116-6 ultimately included a limit of $9.285 billion. The President also requested $551 million for GSA's operating accounts, an increase of $216 million more than FY2018. The President's FY2019 budget request included funding for various initiatives, such as $31 million for the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund, $6 million for the Environmental Review Improvement Fund, and $210 million for the Technology Modernization Fund. These funds are intended to support actions related to public buildings reform, environmental review process reform, and agency information technology system improvements. In the 115th and 116th Congress, funding for GSA's operating accounts varied between House and Senate proposals. Ultimately, P.L. 116-6 appropriated $299 million for GSA's operating accounts. The Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act includes funding for agencies like FLRA, MSPB, OPM, and OSC. The Federal Labor Relations Authority (FLRA) is an independent federal agency that administers Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively. Certain agencies are excluded from this statute, and the President has the authority to exclude others for national security reasons. The FLRA, along with other agencies like the CIA, GAO, NSA, TVA, and FSIP, resolves disputes related to labor practices and bargaining units. Members of the FLRA and FSIP are appointed by the President for five-year terms. The FLRA conducts representation elections and investigates unfair labor practices, while the FSIP resolves negotiation impasses between federal agencies and labor organizations. The President requested $26.2 million for the FLRA in FY2019, funding 125 FTEs. H.R. 6147, H.R. 21, and H.R. 648 all included the same amount. The MSPB requested $44.5 million for FY2019, funding 235 FTEs. The MSPB requested $44.5 million for FY2019 to fund 235 FTEs, maintaining the same level as FY2018. The agency justified the request by explaining that their revised FTE level is 226 to align with decreased personnel compensation and benefits. The funding would support their statutory responsibilities of processing appeals from Federal employees and issuing study reports. In the 115th Congress, H.R. 6147 proposed $46.8 million for MSPB, $2.3 million more than the President's request. In the 116th Congress, both H.R. 21 and H.R. 648 included $46.8 million for the MSPB, as did the enacted P.L. 116-6. The President's budget requested $132.2 million for OPM salaries and expenses, including funds for IT infrastructure modernization and acquisition workforce capabilities. The budget requested appropriations for trust fund transfers, OPM OIG salaries and expenses, and OIG trust fund transfers for FY2019. OPM requested a decrease in FTE employment level for FY2019 to address critical IT infrastructure and investments for security posture. The request also aims to enable OPM OIG to conduct agency-wide audits, investigations, and oversight for IT infrastructure projects. In the 115th and 116th Congress, funding for OPM salaries, expenses, and trust fund transfers was included in various bills. Directives were given to OPM for Federal Retirement Processing Modernization, emphasizing the need for automated electronic filing systems. OPM was directed to provide monthly reports to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees on progress in addressing backlogs and organizational changes. The House committee emphasized the importance of OPM's mission in directing human resources and employee management services, administering retirement benefits, managing healthcare and insurance programs, overseeing hiring in the civil service, and providing updates to Congress through the OPM Inspector General. The House committee directed OPM to improve federal hiring processes, reduce barriers to employment, and increase recruitment efforts at various institutions. They also emphasized the importance of OPM's role in managing human resources, retirement benefits, and healthcare programs. The House committee directed OPM to track government-wide data on special pay authorities to improve employee recruitment and retention. They also supported well-managed telework programs for cost savings and productivity improvements. The Senate committee urged OPM to work with agencies to improve telework data collection methods and set goals for telework results. The Senate committee directed OPM to provide updates on transitioning DOD background investigations, strengthen internal controls for official time, implement IT modernization recommendations, and provide a spending plan for the Trust Fund Federal Financial System. The Senate committee directed OPM to provide a spending plan for the $18.4 million allocated to the FFS initiative, options for modernization, and a timeline for completion within 30 days. They also addressed the need for internal controls to prevent premature closure of investigations and encouraged OPM to include cybersecurity efforts in their semiannual report to Congress. The 116th Congress conference report (H.Rept. 116-9) maintained OPM's cybersecurity policies and procedures, oversight of IT service contractors, and compliance with government-wide cybersecurity initiatives. Additionally, OPM was directed to submit a report on the budgetary implications of relocating Human Resources Solutions (HRS) to the General Services Administration (GSA) within 30 days of the act's enactment. The OPM Revolving Fund established by 5 U.S.C. §1304(e)(1) to GSA. OPM is directed to provide quarterly updates on the status of the HRS program relocation and other relocations. H.R. 6147 in the 115th Congress would have provided mandatory appropriations for health benefits, life insurance, and retirement accounts. The House Committee on Appropriations estimated $13.5 billion for employee health benefits, $49 million for employee life insurance, and $8 billion for the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund in the 116th Congress. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21, H.R. 648, and P.L. 116-6 allocated $21.628 billion to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) requested $26.3 million for FY2019 with an estimated FTE employment level of 144, an increase from 131 FTEs in FY2018. The agency projected stable intakes of whistleblower disclosure, Hatch Act, and prohibited personnel practice cases at around 6,000 new cases per year. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) requested funding to meet rising demand for services, protect whistleblowers in the VA and other agencies, manage increasing case levels, and safeguard the federal merit system. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21, H.R. 648, and P.L. 116-6 allocated $26.5 million for the OSC, slightly more than the President's request. The Senate committee report highlighted the increase in VA cases and directed funding towards addressing the issue. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) requested funding to address the significant increase in VA cases. The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) requested $376.8 million for FY2019. In the 115th Congress, H.R. 6147 as passed by the House would have appropriated $390.7 million, whereas H.R. 6147 as passed by the Senate would have appropriated $393.4 million. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21 and H.R. 648 would have appropriated $393.4 million and $391.3 million respectively. P.L. 116-6 appropriated $391.3 million. NARA's funding includes $27.2 million for debt repayment related to Archives II construction. The NCUA manages the CDRLF to assist low-income credit unions with loans and grants for community development. Loans are typically repaid in five years, with grants available for various purposes such as improving operations. The CDRLF may use earnings to fund loans or grants. In the 115th and 116th Congress, appropriations for the CDRLF varied, with the Office of Government Ethics overseeing financial disclosure and ethics in the executive branch. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) oversees financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics in the executive branch. OGE provides education and training to ethics officials but does not investigate or prosecute ethics violations. The President's FY2019 request for OGE was $16.3 million, with appropriations varying in the 115th and 116th Congress. Ultimately, P.L. 116-6 appropriated $17 million for OGE. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was established in 2004 and reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch in 2007. The five-member board focuses on ensuring privacy and civil liberties concerns are considered in laws and policies related to terrorism prevention. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was established in 2004 as an independent agency within the executive branch to analyze and review actions taken to protect the nation from terrorism while balancing privacy and civil liberties. The board advises the President and executive branch departments, provides annual reports to Congress, and testifies before congressional committees. The President requested $5 million for the PCLOB in FY2019, which was appropriated in P.L. 116-6. The PCAOB, created by Sarbanes-Oxley, is funded through accounting fees. It offers scholarships funded by penalties. For FY2018, not more than $1 million was allocated for scholarships. In the 115th Congress, Section 620 of H.R. 6147 allocated $1 million for scholarships funded by penalties collected by the PCAOB. The Administration did not request funding for these scholarships in FY2019. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21, H.R. 648, and P.L. 116-6 all included the same Section 620 language with $1 million in spending for scholarships in FY2019. The SEC enforces securities laws to protect investors from fraud. The SEC enforces securities laws to protect investors from fraud and ensure accurate financial information disclosure. The agency's budget is offset by fees collected from securities exchanges, making it deficit-neutral. The FY2019 budget request totaled $1.699 billion, with a portion allocated for lease costs. In the 115th Congress, both House and Senate versions of H.R. 6147 appropriated $1.696 billion for the SEC. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21 and H.R. 648 proposed appropriations of $1.696 billion and $1.712 billion respectively. P.L. 116-6 allocated $1.712 billion, including funds for the New York Regional Office lease. The Dodd-Frank Act established an SEC reserve fund funded by registration fees, capped at $100 million annually. The President requested $25 million be rescinded from the FY2019 budget. The President requested $25 million be rescinded from the reserve fund in FY2019. The Selective Service System is an independent federal agency that serves the military's emergency manpower needs by conscripting personnel when directed by Congress and the President. Most males aged 18 through 25 in the United States are required to register with the SSS. The draft was terminated in 1973 and has not been renewed. In 1980, President Carter requested standby draft registration for both men and women, with funds approved for male-only registration. Women can now serve in combat units, potentially leading to their inclusion in registration. The Selective Service System's funding has remained stable in absolute dollars but decreased in inflation-adjusted terms. For FY2019, $26.4 million was requested, with $26 million appropriated by Congress. This represents a $3.1 million increase over the previous year. The Small Business Administration (SBA) administers programs to assist small businesses, including loan guarantees, low-interest loans for disaster victims, training programs, federal contracting oversight, and advocacy. The President requested $834.1 million for the SBA in FY2019, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loan administration, and other programs. The Administration requested $155.2 million for business loan administration, $4 million for business loan subsidy costs, $21.9 million for the Office of the Inspector General, $9.1 million for the Office of Advocacy, and $186.5 million for disaster assistance. Authorization levels were also requested for various loan guaranty programs and program revisions were proposed. The 115th Congress House-passed H.R. 6147 included appropriations for the SBA for FY2019, with $741.88 million allocated, $92.2 million less than the Administration's request. The bill included funding for salaries, entrepreneurial development, noncredit programs, and disaster assistance. Additionally, the bill proposed changes to fee structures and an increase in the SBAExpress program's maximum loan amount. The House-passed bill for FY2019 included appropriations for the SBA, with $741.88 million allocated, $92.2 million less than the Administration's request. The bill proposed changes to fee structures and an increase in the SBAExpress program's maximum loan amount. The Senate-passed H.R. 6147 allocated $699.3 million for the SBA, $134.8 million less than the Administration's request, with funding for salaries, entrepreneurial development, and noncredit programs. No funding was provided for disaster assistance. The SBA is set to increase loan guarantee program authorization levels and fee structures. The Senate-passed H.R. 6147 includes provisions to restrict SBA assistance to businesses with ties to China, study matchmaking services for veterans, and review compliance with federal contract requirements. In the 116th Congress, $715.37 million was appropriated for the SBA, $134.8 million less than requested. In the 116th Congress, P.L. 116-6 appropriated $715.37 million for the SBA, with allocations for various programs including salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loan administration, and disaster assistance. Authorization levels were set for loan guaranty programs and the Small Business Investment Company program as requested by the Trump Administration. The Trump Administration authorized the Small Business Administration (SBA) to transfer up to 3% of its funding to a System Modernization and Working Capital Fund (IT WCF) for improving information technology systems and cybersecurity. The fund will remain available for obligation until September 30, 2022. The U.S. Postal Service generates nearly $70 billion annually from mail users for its services. The U.S. Postal Service receives nearly $70 billion annually from mail users. Congress provides appropriations to compensate for revenue lost in providing free mailing privileges. The Revenue Forgone Reform Act authorizes annual reimbursements until 2035. Funds are deposited in the Postal Service Fund for operating expenses. The Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act (PAEA) affects the postal appropriations process by requiring the USPSOIG and the PRC to submit budget requests directly to Congress and OMB. Funding for these agencies must come from the Postal Service Fund. The President requested $55.2 million for the Postal Service Fund in FY2019, which is $2.9 million less than the previous year. Congress proposed different appropriations for the USPS in the 115th Congress. In the 116th Congress, appropriations for the Postal Service Fund varied between the House and Senate versions of H.R. 6147, with amounts ranging from $55.2 million to $250 million. The President requested $234.7 million for the USPSOIG in FY2019, which was a decrease from the previous year's appropriation. Additionally, funding for the PRC in FY2019 was requested at $15.1 million, slightly lower than the previous year's allocation. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21, H.R. 648, and P.L. 116-6 allocated $15.2 million for the Postal Regulatory Commission (PRC). The President's FY2019 Budget proposed operational reforms for USPS, such as discontinuing six-day mail delivery and allowing for a one-time postal rate increase. The House and Senate versions of H.R. 6147 in the 115th Congress included provisions to maintain six-day mail delivery and provide free mail services for overseas voting and the blind. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21, H.R. 648, and P.L. 116-6 included long-standing postal policy provisions but did not incorporate the policy reforms from the President's FY2019 Budget. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over tax matters, headquartered in Washington, DC, and appropriated $50.7 million in FY2018. The President requested $55.6 million for FY2019. In the 116th Congress, H.R. 21, H.R. 648, and P.L. 116-6 included $51.5 million for the United States Tax Court (USTC). The FSGG Appropriations Act contains general provisions that apply government-wide, with new provisions proposed for FY2019 appropriations acts. The OMB Director will adjust FY2019 discretionary spending limits by 0.2% for estimating differences with CBO. Covered agencies can transfer funds to IT Fund for modernization purposes. The FY2019 budget proposal allows agencies to transfer funds to their IT Fund for modernization purposes, with transferred amounts remaining available for three fiscal years. Additionally, funds cannot be used to enforce a rule requiring disclosure of conflict minerals' origin in certain countries. The FY2019 budget proposal allows agencies to transfer funds to their IT Fund for modernization purposes, with transferred amounts remaining available for three fiscal years. A pay adjustment of 1.9% for 2019 was authorized for federal civilian employees paid under the General Schedule, allocated as 1.4% base pay adjustment and 0.5% locality pay adjustment. The Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control administers the main body of Cuba embargo regulations, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, which have been amended over the years to reflect changes in U.S. policy toward Cuba. In the 115th Congress, provisions in Division B of H.R. 6147 aimed to tighten U.S. economic sanctions on Cuba. The provision in Section 129 of H.R. 6147 aimed to prohibit the use of funds to approve licenses related to confiscated Cuban property, specifically targeting the importation of rum and tobacco products. It also addressed a dispute between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited regarding trademark registration fees. The dispute between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited over the Havana Club trademark was addressed in legislation, including a specific license issued by OFAC in 2016. However, provisions related to Cuba were not included in the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018.
